title: Train to Busan
content: Train to Busan follows some pretty simple character arcs and story beats, but it's so much fun and so well crafted that it doesn't really matter.There are some predictable key plot points from the beginning. We know the father, stuck in business mode so often he can't even remember what gifts he's given his daughter over the years, will become more compassionate and present by the end. And we know that the evil characters will get theirs before the credits roll. But you know what? Those are the kind of story elements that can be very exciting in the right place. I want to see evil people get what they deserve. I want to see the business man become a good father. And I want to see the kind hearted child survive despite the selfish adults who surround her. These are moments that have me cheering the movie on even if I kind of already know where it's heading. It's like a warm blanket covered in zombie guts. I feel comfortable and disgusted all in one.Even with all this said, the movie is undeniably exciting. Action scenes are well shot and never feel too closed in to see what's happening. This is a very real concern for a movie that takes place predominantly on a train.There was an honest sense of loss when some characters died too. While most of them were underdeveloped there were a few that I felt like I really got to know in just under 2 hours. I think that was mostly due to some really great performances. It's all in their faces. Dong-seok Ma knocked it outta the park. He came off so smug at first but then evolves into your manly, trustworthy dad who doesn't know how to change his ringtone. It's so good. Su-an Kim is another standout. She is so quiet and reserved at the start, then as things continue to fall apart around her she has so much opportunity to show a range of emotions like anguish and fear. She killed it. This is a great child performance.The cg and make up effects are phenomenal. Some that were especially impressive were the zombie movements and the zombie deer in the opening. They sometimes looked a bit off but that only added to the charm.

title: A whole lotta murder on an Orient Express
content: Intense and engaging but overlong and occasionally overwrought. The music, apart from some interesting use of train whistles, is melodramatic and at times jarring. Some great set pieces-the sneak sequence as well as an arrival that goes awry stands out when credits roll-but Jack Nicholsons concise drive-by-critique of Jacksons "The Return of the King" comes to mind:"Too many endings."There are precisely two end points in the last 15 minutes that would provide a better ending than the one we finally get. Emotional, ambiguous, beautifully shot. Plus, we would have found at least 10-15 of the 20-30 minutes that needs to be shaved off to elevate this from a strong 6 to a pulpy and Cormanesque 8 or 9.It never comes close to the grandeur and thoughtfulness of Snowpiercer (South Korean directors seem to have a thing for trains), nor the sublime poetry of the train ride in Spirited Away, but arrives in better time than Unstoppable and Bullet Train. Oh, and Transsiberian may have reached its destination before all of them.

title: One of The Most Sound Inspections Inside Horror Sub-Genre
content: Current walkers' genre arises from horror/survival films chiefly, which located its golden years at the end of the 1960s, where the sub- genre genesis was cemented with a brand new and unique solvency, the same one that slaughters the audience as genuine vultures without any substance. Although there's not an accurate date about when it was considered preeminent in the celluloid world, but we do know the three men who reflected heterogeneity and universal depth that an undead horde may originate. title: Not that good
content: A farmer is stopped at some decontamination checkpoint. There's some leak at a biotech plant.Next we meet the boss of some investment firm. He's of course too busy to pay attention to his young daughter who wants to visit her mom in Busan. The dad finally agrees and they make it to the train station. On they way there's something going on, lots of emergency vehicles are driving somewhere. As the train departs zombies attack the train station and one actually makes it on the train.This zombie attacks some train attendant who bites another one and so on. Here the transformation into a zombie is near instantaneous. Depending on the needs of the script it may happen right away or it may take a minute or two. When eventually the passengers catch on what is going on, they run to the front of the train while the zombies end up in the rear. But by now the condition is spreading all over South Korea. The train isn't allowed to stop somewhere, communications are interrupted.We meet several characters: a pregnant woman and her tougher husband, two older women, a young baseball team, an even more arrogant and selfish business guy, and the train conductor.They do stop in some town where people would be quarantined by the military. But when they arrive and leave the train the military personnel is also infected. So it's back on the train but this time a group is in the back another in the rear. The ones in the back--our heroes--have to make it to the front where people are so freaked out they won't let them in.Things get grimmer and we'll have to see who actually survives this disaster as they get closer and closer to Busan.Train to Busan is a long, slow, melodramatic thriller with zombies piled up--I guess that's going to be the new trend thanks to World War Z, piles and piles of quick zombies. Despite the penchant for drama there's little dialogue and the characters' behavior often doesn't make a whole lot of sense mainly because for some reason they have nothing to say to each other. The zombie action is quick, somewhat unclear, individual zombies matter little but masses of zombies falling out of train cars like cockroaches are emphasized. None of it is particularly scary or frightening, which it should be given that the humans in a train have only two places to go- to the front or to the back. There's not a whole lot of gore or violence. What is good though is the setting of a zombie movie in a train; and I also liked that the movie takes place mostly during the day.It's surprising that while this movie does point out the soullessness of business people it also makes one of them the hero. We do get some sense of Korean values--rigidity, deference to authority, overemphasis on education as a solution to all ills.I can't quite understand the high score of this movie. It is perfectly mediocre and stands out in no way whatsoever.

title: A Masterpiece
content: Just saw this for the first time on Netflix. It's about having the strength of character to do what is right and sacrifice yourself for your family and friends and to fight to the death against odds you know are impossibly against you.A very inspiring father-daughter story set against a backdrop of a zombie apocalypse happening in South Korea, Train to Busan is much more than just another zombie movie.Something I also liked that this movie pulls no punches and respects for the viewer's intelligence. The characters solve problems through clever means. There are no deus ex machina elements present. The gore and violence is shown with a disturbing steadiness rather than being over the top. The zombies themselves are portrayed moreso as humans with rabies than anything else. They don't run super fast, they don't have super strength, and they are not exceptionally durable. In this sense, the zombies are more believable. The female characters in the film are not endowed with Hollywood-ized GIRL POWER. Some of them do demonstrate bravery, but scenes are not written purely to push feminist agendas.The acting of everyone in the film was great. Exceptional credit must go to the little girl who plays the daughter of the lead actor. She was amazing and executed every scene she was in perfectly.Highly recommended.

title: One-Way Ticket to Busan, Fear and Sweat Included
content: Imagine a packed Korean train where every stop is a new sprint into hell. Train to Busan takes the zombie concept and throws it at you at 300 km/h. No fluff here, just hordes hungry for human flesh and characters sweating panic, with no time to breathe. It's not a stroll; it's an emotional crash test.Korean cinema isn't just stylish - here, it hits hard and direct, with no frills. On a budget far from US blockbusters, Sang-Ho Yeon has turned his train into a stage for pure dread. Sure, it doesn't shy away from clichés, but it elevates them. The characters are so vivid that you dread seeing them die. Merging the personal with the chaos? That's a masterstroke.These zombies aren't Romero's slow walkers. They sprint, they're aggressive, tearing into flesh at high speed. Each train car becomes a survival challenge. And then you've got twists that land like slaps. This train is a pressure cooker, with tension building at every moment. Hang on tight; you're on a one-way journey with no return.A stellar cast brings characters that feel real, even if some, like the "businessman," are straight-up caricatures. But you still get attached. You love them, you hate them, and every loss is a punch. The film plays with us, manipulates us, and we can't get enough.Some will see a social critique here: selfishness, sacrifice, solidarity under extreme pressure. What's certain is that it hits hard. While other films might deliver speeches, here it's visual, brutal, and sometimes even moving. You leave feeling exhausted but glad to have survived until the credits.An absolute success, with no concessions. Sang-Ho Yeon has created a masterpiece that blends catastrophe, tension, and action like we rarely see. If you love films that keep you on edge, Train to Busan is a ride you won't want to miss.

title: Last Stop: Survival
content: Train to Busan, directed by Yeon Sang-ho, is a relentless and emotional journey that redefines the zombie genre, blending high-octane action with a powerful story of survival, sacrifice, and humanity. Set aboard a speeding train from Seoul to Busan during a sudden zombie outbreak, the film follows Seok-woo (Gong Yoo), a workaholic father traveling with his young daughter, Su-an (Kim Su-an). As they and other passengers fight to stay alive in the confined spaces of the train, the story explores the human cost of survival, highlighting both the best and worst of human nature in a crisis.Gong Yoo gives a standout performance as Seok-woo, capturing the character's transformation from a self-centred businessman to a protective and selfless father. Gong's portrayal is grounded and empathetic, making his character's journey all the more impactful. Kim Su-an's performance as Su-an is equally remarkable, bringing a sense of innocence and emotional vulnerability that heightens the film's stakes. The chemistry between father and daughter adds a deeply emotional core to the action, grounding the intense scenes with moments of tenderness and humanity.The direction by Yeon Sang-ho is masterful, keeping the pace relentless while maintaining clarity in the action. The tight, confined setting of the train amplifies the tension, creating a claustrophobic environment that heightens the fear and desperation of each encounter. The cinematography captures both the adrenaline-fuelled chaos and quieter moments with precision, while the dynamic camerawork brings viewers into the heart of the action, immersing them fully in the characters' fight for survival.What sets Train to Busan apart from typical zombie films is its rich character development and exploration of social themes. The film delves into themes of selflessness, family, and the sacrifices made in the face of tragedy. The script skilfully portrays the moral struggles of each character, emphasising the importance of solidarity and empathy in a world torn apart by fear. Through its diverse cast of passengers, Train to Busan examines human nature under extreme pressure, revealing the courage, cowardice, and compassion that define us.Train to Busan is more than just a thrilling zombie film; it's an emotionally resonant story that reminds us of the power of sacrifice and the resilience of the human spirit. Its perfect blend of action, horror, and heart makes it a standout in the genre and a powerful cinematic experience that lingers long after the credits roll. It is a masterpiece that has set a new standard for zombie films, capturing audiences worldwide with its intensity, heart, and humanity.

title: A Ferocious Bite Of Living Dead Excellency
content: I had this movie sitting on my "YouView" box for quite a few months, even though I had been originally excited that Film4 had decided to air this "little" Korean gem of a horror movie. There had been rave reviews and more than a slight "buzz" about the picture. The trouble with me is that I've been let down by hyped movies before - The Blair Witch Project, a major case by example. Another trouble is my own little foibles. I don't want to be reading subtitles when I'm tired (and I do so love to watch horror flicks after the sun has set with the lights low... or off!) and I cannot stand dubbed films (too many Jackie Chan movies in my youth...). So one night, not so very long ago I was feeling awake enough to read a movie so I hit play on "Train To Busan"...By the time the end credits rolled I was amped up and wide awake. This is one hell of a rollercoaster ride of a movie and one hell of a tangle of modern-day lives story. This is not your basic Zombie flick.You start out really slowly and pretty sedated. A farmer is on his way to the market when his van is stopped by men in hazmat suits. These tell him that there's nothing to worry about. There has been a slight leak at a chemical plant. After quickly decontaminating his vehicle they send him on his way... unluckily for the dear he runs down and kills. More angry at damaging his van than killing a dear he drives away leaving the carcass in the road... yeah... you know what's going to happen. Sure enough, the dead animal thrashes about and shakily gets to its feet... with a dead look in its eyes...Even though this section only takes a few minutes it's one of the most superbly shot sequences I've seen in a movie. The director Yeon Sang Ho manipulates each set perfectly give the audience a creepily eerie atmosphere, which did start the shivers running up and down my spine. For that I thank them... it's been a long time since that's happened. There's nice steady sweeping camera pans. Effortlessly worked lighting. Superb control of sound... or lack of it. Even better is that all of this artwork and skill doesn't stop here it runs throughout the whole movie. It screams skill and class.Then the writers, Park Joo Suk and Yeon Sang Ho, get to work weaving together tales of modern-day living. The main characters are Seok-Woo (Gong Yoo) and his daughter Soo-Ann (Kim Su An). He is a busy, work-comes-first-to-support-family guy who was already lost his wife to divorce and is now bringing up Soo-Ann, with the help of his mother. Soo-Ann is a young child who doesn't understand or appreciate her father's outlook on life. All she knows is that she doesn't see either him or her mother as much as she wants or should. She wants more time with both of her parents. So, on her birthday, after her dad buys her a repeat present (who doesn't need two Nintendo Wii's(?)) she gets him to promise to take her to see her mum for her real present. As is the usual case it's Su-An Kim's performance that steals the show - and this is as it should be.This then brings them into contact with Sang-Hwa (Ma Dong Seok) and his very expectant wife Seong-Kyeong (Jung Yu Mi). Sang-Hwa and Seok-Woo do not get on at all and it's this juxtaposition in ideals and prerogatives that add more depth to the story; especially when they have to work together to survive the train ride. It's Seong-Kyeong that provides the glue to their relationship.Add to this a mysterious homeless man (Choi Gwi Hwa), a couple of romantic teens getting to grips with their feelings towards each other - Yong-Guk (Choi Woo Sic) and Jin-Hee (Sohee), and officious self-centred train manager Yon-Suk (Kim Eui Sung), you have a set of characters which can create some volatile or sentimental storylines... and this is before we get to the best Zombies... EVER!One of my favourite zombie flicks is Return Of The Living Dead. Two of the reasons were the zombies - they were dead and very icky (most were skinless)... and they were fast. The brain-eating buggers didn't shamble after you. And you have the same here. Though these dead aren't so skinless they are damned fast and furious.This adds to some pretty spectacular action scenes in the movie which Yuen Sang Ho directs magnificently. But, whereas, most directors would opt for action over horror and story Yuen is proficient in all styles. The scenes where the dead reanimate are both startling, invigorating, eerie, and full of style and strength.This is a tour-de-force of filmmaking, let alone horror filmmaking. Everything in this movie is excellent, from the story to the acting to the directing.

title: Because hollywood has become sub-garbage doesn't mean you should give everything foreign a 10?
content: I'm French and I watch movies from all over the world - if it's good, it's good. If it's bad, it's bad. Simple, right?A movie is not 'incredible' because it's 'made in (insert country)'. Sure, Holly-Bolly-wood(s) cornerned the markets, and sure, it's nice in an age of absurd globalization to see a movie left untouched by the 'screeching minorities' of SJWs complainign about under-representation of whatever (insert 'thing of month') Try that crap in China, Korea or well, anywhere outside 'the west'. Good luck.But because it's not the rock-bottom garbage from Netflix, still doesn't make "Train to Busan" not "I Stand Alone (1998)" while neither is Yeon Sang-ho the Korean Lars von Triers. Because a Korean director can ape Hollywood and even beat it at its own game on a shoestring budget, doesn't mean the movie is 'great art' or even 'memorable'.Sure, "Train to Busan" saves us from the habitual k-wave of 60fps, cheap drama/romance from Hallyu 3.0. But make no mistake: it's just jumping from one mold (K-drama) to another (Hollywood blockbuster) to rake in the $$$ just like in LA. No difference there.In fact, I'd go as far as saying that it's not even to the zombie genre what Hard Boiled (1992) was to "Lethal Weapon". Because at least Chinese "gun-fu" was original and fresh back then, while the 'fast zombie' trope had more than welcome its welcome by 2010. And "Train" was shot in 2016.Finally, while the end scene is a solid tear-jerker because it has the odd particularity of tying the movie together, the same cannot be said for everything that preceded that ending and , if you were to think about it for more than 3 minutes, just a by-the-numbers "coureageous hero" vs "cowardly vilain" dichotomy without much interest.

title: Absolute masterpiece!
content: Man, South Korea has got it going on! I happened on this movie randomly, completely unaware of its fame and awards offshore. I watched it simply wondering what is a Korean zombie movie like because I had been long over the genre and especially The Walking Dead. What I watched was character development at its most refined fineness.Seok-woo starts as a typical father working much harder at his job than at his relationship with his daughter. The quickly unfolding and non-stop dangerous turn of events reveals what is most important to him, and shows he is not cold, that he does have a heart. The flashback at the end...as a father, I cried.Sang-hwa's crass, rude nature initially paints him as a selfish oaf who thinks he's better than everyone else. The quickly unfolding and non-stop dangerous turn of events reveals that he is quite the opposite. He is selfless, has a great sense of humor, and is the kind of person you'd prefer at your side if you were dealing with a zombie breakout.What director Sang-ho Yeon focuses on is not the action or the scares, but the characters. How they respond to the circumstances that challenge their ability to survive and care for others is like seeing a flower bloom. I feel like his whole point of the movie was to make us ask ourselves "Who are we truly?" We got bogged down with our careers. We take relationships for granted. We act hardcore in non threatening situations. But what happens when hysteria and danger overwhelm your atmosphere? Who do you care about most then? What's the absolute most important thing in your life? I'll tell you again...the ending. Ugh, I cried watching a zombie movie!

title: another level of zombie movie
content: This film is more than just a standard zombie thriller-it's a deeply emotional and gripping narrative that explores the lengths people will go to for survival and the bonds that are forged during catastrophic events. The pacing is relentless, as the action kicks off almost immediately and rarely lets up. Director Yeon Sang-ho masterfully balances high-octane action sequences with poignant character moments, especially between Seok-woo and his daughter. The film effectively uses the claustrophobic setting of the train to heighten the tension, making every encounter with the infected feel like a ticking time bomb. There's a real sense of danger in every scene, and it's not just from the zombies, but from the desperation of the human survivors as well.On top of the action, the film also touches on important themes such as selflessness, greed, and the power of community. The relationship between Seok-woo and his daughter adds a touching layer to the story, making the stakes feel incredibly personal. Each character has a distinct role and brings something unique to the table, and the sacrifices made throughout the movie are heart-wrenching. By the time you reach the emotional climax, you're not just scared of the zombies-you're fully invested in the characters' fates. Train to Busan is a rollercoaster of emotions and thrills, delivering both scares and heartfelt moments, which is why it's often considered one of the best zombie films ever made.

title: Stuck on a Train with Zombies and Nowhere to Escape
content: "Seok-woo" (Yoo Gong) is a fund manager who spends all of his time at the office which has subsequently damaged his marriage beyond repair. As luck would have it, however, he happens to have his young daughter "Soo-an" (Su-an Kim) with him for a few days and to cheer her up agrees to accompany her on the morning train from Seoul to Busan to be with her mother. However, upon boarding the train they discover that a zombie apocalypse has just started in Korea and that they are trapped inside one of the passenger cars with no ability to escape. As a result the uninfected passengers are forced to band together to keep the determined zombies as bay. Now rather than reveal any more I will just say that this was a fairly solid zombie film which emphasized the ultra-fast variety in lieu of the typical slow-moving type. Because of that the action is quite brisk which initially worked quite well for the majority of the film. Unfortunately, I must admit that the non-stop action tended to become somewhat tedious after a while. Likewise, the rather poor ending didn't exactly help in that regard either. In any case, as I stated earlier this was a decent zombie movie for the most part and I have rated it accordingly. Average.

title: This emotionally charged and zombie filled train is worth boarding
content:
Train To Busan (2016)
Rating: 4/5When you are about to watch a film in the zombie genre, you have two things in mind:
1) A lot many are going to die.
2) Zombies will provide us much gore.
Well "Train To Busan" has all that in plenty, but what it has which many zombie films lack is: Emotional depth. Throughout the film we are able to connect to each character. A fund manager, who is estranged from his wife, and fails to live up to his daughter's expectations; A strongly built man and his pregnant wife; a baseball player and a girl who loves him; a selfish as hell man; two old women who are sisters and many more form characters who are fighting for survival from zombies, in a train which is travelling to Busan. Will they survive?Director Yeon Sang-ho makes sure that while he shows the undead masses of bodies attacking the passengers of the train, we are connected to each of them. "Train to Busan" is a story of survival, compassion, sacrifice. It shows us how human beings act together to fight something bigger, which felt timely as we are in the midst of a pandemic ourselves. Then there's ones who are selfish. Take this scene as an example: The fund manager and all are trying to enter another compartment of the train, but the passengers of that compartment are paranoid that they might be infected, and they try to stop them from entering.While there's gore, but the film doesn't overdo that. There's some humour sprinkled, like the scene where the pregnant woman's husband asks the fund manager's daughter whether he's her real dad, as he initially didn't like her father. There's humour, but there's the seriousness which runs throughout the film. From the opening scene where a dead deer comes back to life, we know that things are about to become tense and the entire film is very tense but entertaining.There was a scene in the film which I found a bit absurd: the fund manager, the pregnant woman's husband and the baseball player deciding to fight their way to reach their people felt a odd choice that a person would make in such a situation and I wanted the film to make more impact. But, this emotionally charged and zombie filled train is worth boarding.
